pros: Flexible hours, a lot of downtime to do homework.
cons: Only up to 20 hours a week.
Salary and benefits, as well as limited parking.

pros: Flexible and family friendly place to work. Very kind and helpful people.
cons: Pay isn't great, but it helps working for such a flexible and kind place.

pros: - student workers are always fun to work with
cons:
- Felt impossible to recruit for such a small, outdated university (and the admissions numbers/ retention rates obviously show that)
- Disconnected from alumni and partners: While on the road, I heard alumni say "Oh that picture looks like PCC" and never knew there was a name change (in 1997!) - I feel like alumni would have heard about it within the last 20 years.
- Bought this even worse off school in Nebraska and put way too much focus and attention on it. The campus in Fullerton is where they need to focus, but there isn't enough of that. I think they're constantly looking for ways to save the school, and buying another dying school in the midwest wasn't the answer.
- Meanwhile, they had this insanely nice building over by Angels' stadium for the online advisors and MFT program. I always wondered how and why they paid for something so nice when the main, residential campus was falling apart. You could look out the window and watch a game from the conference room.
- I was micromanaged more than ever in my life - I once I had write down a list of what I did every minute, every hour, of everyday (example - 10:22 - bathroom break)
- The school is only held together financially from the athletics department.
- Totally weird place - the president of the university and his wife lived in the dorms!
- No room for raises or advancement.

pros: Good community of people to work with
cons: The job could use more benefits

pros: Great boss with a great view of events
cons: Long periods of time where you are standing

pros:
Nice team members
Fast paced environment, there's always something to do.
cons:
Management resistant to change, disorganized, reactive approach to solutions
High turnover (except for in management .. which is a clear red flag)
Homogeneous culture. Not well educated or informed on diversity/inclusion

pros:
-Steady hours
-fun work environment 
-encouraging team members
- paid sick leave
The people, the community, and family atmosphere.

Almost everyone who works here full time believes in the mission of the university. Students receive the personal attention of faculty, staff and administration that is unheard of in other institutions.
Very collegial spirit among the faculty. Not a lot of turn over in full time faculty positions. People love teaching here and stay.
The administration has somehow turned things around financially. They've been operating in the black for a number of years, even during the tough economic times.  Actually adding faculty and staff the last few years instead of cutting positions.
cons:
Is is a con to say that you have to love undergraduate students to work here? If you are not interested in student interaction, stay away.
Workloads are heavy. Seems like faculty are asked to do too much (or accept overload) to make up for lower pay.
Tuition driven institution, which means the budget is directly affected by student enrollment each semester.
Seem to be relying heavily on adjunct faculty, which is a trend in all higher ed.

review_title: My experience started off great, but with certain changes in the department it became a terrible working environment.
pros: I learned quite a bit while working in the admissions office. I realized how much some if the faculty cared for the interested students. I was given experience of working with certain data controls, etc.
cons: The biggest was mostly the faculty. Once a new boss was brought in, it became a favoritism game. One of the counselors who had been there for years was recently fired because she did not like him. Another counselor I would watch get disrespected everyday because she also does not like her. It was a real disappointment, especially because it is supposed to be a Christian environment.

pros: Great flexibility of schedule. Loved the management. They had normal and fair expectations but were also very friendly.  If projects were completed, I could work on homework in-between assisting patrons.
cons: Could make more money else where but I chose the lower pay for a job that was on campus and that allowed time to work on homework.

job_title: Development and Marketing Associate in Fullerton, CA
pros: great benefits, such as staff tuition grant, Christian environment
cons: politics, slow growth, low-budgets, lack of communication
